And I don't want to see any frowns about it, all right? Sometimes we don't know the background of things and we miss some of the important little things that are said. I want you to understand that Philippi is a very important city from this standpoint. About 100 years before Paul shows up at Philippi, there was a major battle that took place right outside its gates. Two men, men named Brutus and Cassius, you may remember who Brutus is, et tu Brute? Brutus and Cassius were two of those that murdered Julius Caesar, surprised him with the knives and hundreds of knife thrusts into his body. And he has sided with Octavian, who is a great Roman general. And those two armies, the armies of Brutus and Cassius, meet the army of Mark Anthony and Octavius right outside of the city of Philippi. The citizens of Philippi decide that they're going to aid and help Octavius and Mark Anthony. And those two win the battle. You say, this is fascinating stuff, preacher. Now, wait a minute. Here's what becomes important. Octavius became Caesar. And he so appreciated what the Philippians did, what that city of Philippi did, that he conferred on them every citizen of Philippi. From that point on, their children were born Roman citizens. Philippi actually becomes a Roman colony and a Roman capital in that area. And those who would have never had any hope of Roman citizenship are now made Roman citizens. You say, why is that important? Well, it's important for a number of reasons. Look at verse 12. And so what you did, if you were a Hebrew, if you were a Jew, you were instructed that if there was no synagogue, if you were in a city, that on the Sabbath day you were to find a quiet spot by the river, if there was a river or a park, some quiet spot where you worship the Lord. Now isn't that interesting that Paul and his missionary party went to the riverside? They didn't just go to the riverside because there was a park there. They went to the riverside because they knew there would be people who were pious at that riverside. And when they arrive at that riverside, they begin to preach the gospel. There's an important statement that's made in verse 11. Would you see it? He says, for I have learned. The life of a missionary, if you study the Apostle Paul's life and others, is not an easy one. I close with this, 1956, four young men, four young men, actually five, a fifth will join them, moved their families to Ecuador, to Quito, Ecuador. One of those men was named Jim Elliott, and he so wanted to reach one particular tribe, the Aucas. They had had some success in reaching other tribes, but the Auca Indians in Ecuador were a serious business. They were killers. They had killed a number of workers on oil plantations. They had killed others who had tried to come into their camp and talk with them and civilize them, if you will. But Jim Elliott and others had a real desire to reach them. They came up with a plan. Nate Saint was a pilot, he had a little plane, and he would fly over and drop gifts, and then they figured out a way to drop a bucket down, and they would put gifts in. And one day, after a couple of weeks of this, the Aucas actually sent a gift back up. And they thought, this is it, we can reach them, they're open to us now. And Nate Saint found a little place, a little strip to land on right by the river, and Jim Elliott went in, he dropped Jim off, and then three more trips to take the other three in. And they at first seemed to be making headway with the Auca Indians. But all of it was a ruse. Not long after that first day, two Auca women came out of the jungle on the other side of the river. And they seemed to be coming in peace and seemed to be offering to talk. And Elliott and another man got into the river and started a cross to them. And as they were doing that, they heard a rustling behind them, and Auca men had jumped out of the woods with spears and bows and arrows, and were coming quickly, and there was no doubt what was in their mind, they were going to kill Jim Elliott, Nate Saint, and the others who were in the river. Now here's the unbelievable thing. Jim Elliott had a pistol in his coat. He reached in to draw the pistol, and someone else looked at him and he looked at them because they had made a pact that the only thing they would use the pistol for was protection from animals. They would not kill an Auca Indian because they knew that soul was lost. Jim Elliott, Nate Saint, and three others were killed in that river that day. When they could have protected themselves. He wrote this, and to me it's incredible. Jim Elliott wrote, he is no fool who gives what he cannot keep to gain what he cannot lose. Sometimes we are so careful about holding on to everything we have here. To making sure that we're cared for here, and I'm a planner, I'm not for just being foolish. But I am saying this to you, that we owe a debt. And missions is the way that we can pay that debt. And God calls missionaries to go into places to do things that I don't want to do. But they're not the only ones who have to live by faith. We are called to live by faith. And we are called to be the rope holders. We are called to be the ones who give so that they can go. And I'm telling you, it takes them to sacrifice home and sacrifice a lot of things with family, sacrifice career. But listen, we are called upon to sacrifice. We are called to prioritize. We are called to set one thing above another. We are called to do without sometimes. Boy, not a message our generation wants to hear. But when God sees us say, there's something more important than filling my need, something more important than satisfying my want, I want to share what I have so that they can go, so that they can preach, so that others can hear. And when we make that choice, God goes, that's pleasing, that's acceptable. You ever heard this? You cannot out give God. Well, the proof of it is there in verse 19. God says, when you've got that kind of heart, here's what I do for you, I'll supply all your need. Big circle. With this, I close. You know, I have never seen a U-Haul at a funeral. You ever seen it? I've never seen a hearse pulling a U-Haul because you don't take it with you and because there is something beyond this life. And what Jim Elliott said was, reprioritize. Really look out there at what really is important. Remember where God got you and how God changed your life and find some portion of your heart that can give. That can give. God may be calling you to give your life. He may want you to go. Next time I preach, I want to preach about that. But God is definitely calling us, church, to set right priorities. And souls are the highest priority that God has. Would you pray with me? Father, help us to see truth. I pray that you would speak to our hearts about the priorities in our lives. I don't think you want anybody to be foolish. I don't think you want missionaries to be foolish. But I do think you want us to be sacrificial. I do think you want us to care about souls. I do think you want us to remember where we were when you found us. I do think you want us to consider how you've made our lives better, how you've promised us beyond this life, eternal life. I do think you want us to remember that just as much as you loved us, you love every person in this world. I do think you want us to remember that you want us to bear fruit. God, would you help us to prioritize? Would you help us to struggle with that in our lives? What could we set aside? What could we do without? What could we change? What desire could we put away? What habit could we undo that would allow us to give so that others can hear, so that others can go? Lord, I pray that you would lay on our hearts tonight that it's not just the missionaries who should pay a price, but we ought to be willing to sacrifice too. So in whatever way you desire, I pray you'd speak into the lives of people. Maybe they just need to struggle with their priorities. Maybe they need to make a commitment that they're going to give more so that more can hear. Maybe there's one here tonight that you've been really, you've been dealing with them in their heart and they know that you're dealing with them. Lord, may they just invite you in. And if it's a call to the field, then may they surrender. If it's a call to prioritize, may they make that choice. Lord, I pray you'd help us to see our need. In Jesus' name I pray, amen. I'm gonna ask you to...

it? He says, for I have learned. The life of a missionary, if you study the Apostle Paul's life

up and travel for two years, thousands upon thousands of miles, staying in places you don't

No, I don't feel sorry for them. I'm just trying to be realistic that when we talk about missionaries,

even when circumstances were difficult, even when churches disappointed him, even when nationals

No, I can do all things through the team I work with here on the field. No, men will fail you,

wait a minute. Then he says this in verse 14, notwithstanding. Hey, I've learned how to be

Can I share this with you tonight?
One of the essential things for every one of our lives is this. Remember where God got you.

there, and when God found me and got me, God didn't reach up to a high shelf and

You could have prioritized that money this way, but it's just on your heart to

That from that little offering plate and from your pew, something rises. You say,
